intro: Hookera porrifolia, commonly known as the alpine buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes. It belongs to the family Ranunculaceae and is characterized by its showy, yellow flowers that bloom in the spring. The plant has a low-growing habit with hairy stems and leaves that are divided into lobes. Hookera porrifolia thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in rocky or alpine meadows. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies in mountainous ecosystems.
